document.text: Yvonne Ferguson, Janice McClenny, Naiicy Martin, Virginia Rush, Joan Weeks and Barbara Wooldridge. - The iS. C. A. held its installation service on Wednesday. The newly electd officers were installed at this time. They are pictured elsewhere in todays paper. Mr. H. E. Kerr, principal, award ed a certifícate of recognition to the S. C. A. for this year. This certifi cate was issued by the State S. C. A. in recognition of the outstand ing accomplishments of this organi zation. He also awarded at this time awards for outstanding accomplish ments in the Forensic Club. Shawn Mabley, Carol Myers, Peyton Ab bitt, and Frank Hanenkrat receiv ed awards and medals for their work in the district contests, all winning first places. Well, this is all for this week. See you soon. Peggy-

document.text: Young Tony Ferguson above knows  heart facts from personal experience! He had heart surgery in August of 71 - now plays basketball and is planning on a full season of baseball and football, as well. With Tony is county co- chairman of the Appomattox County Heart Fund, Ivey Holland. County goal is 2,000 to provide research, educational mat erials and equipment

document.text: YOUNG BOXING HOPEFULS shown above from left are Cecil Hunter, 15, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hunter, Randy St. John, 13, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert St. John, Jeff Chauncey, 10, son of Mr. and Mrs. Doyle Chauncey, Gary Ferguson, 11, son of Mrs. Joyce Ferguson, and Jimmy Martin, 15, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Martin. According to Marc Stone, instructor, these young men are really working hard to learn the fundamentals of boxing. The Appomattox Boxing Club, sponsored by the Jaycees, is in its first year and boasts an enrollment of 42. Jaycee President Raymond Mullins has issued a plea for more coaches and trainers and requests that anyone having any experience in boxing and who is willing to donate several hours a Week, contact him or come by the Appomattox Depot on Monday or Wednesday night or Saturday morning. Exercise bicycles are badly needed for training purposes and the loan or donation of one or more will be appreciated. A regulation size ring is under construction and the fighters will soon he practicing what they have been taught. During the next several months there will be tournaments in Appomattox, Charlotte and Richmond with the State Tournament scheduled j in Norfolkon April 21.

document.text: Yesterday was the 100th a n n i versary of the establishment of a U. iS. Post Office at what is bow Appo mattox, Virginia. Information secured from Nation al Archives and the Post Office De partment, Washington, D. C., tells an interesting story of a full cen tury of mail service here. There have been 20 postmaster andor acting postmaster ap pointments in the 100 years of operation and the incumbent, E. LeRoy Smith, has served longer than any other. The name of the office has been changed several times. On February 23, 1855, a fourth class post office was established here and was call ed Nebraska, Virginia. The first postmaster was Samuel D. McDear- mon. Salary amounted to 6.01. The office operated under the name of Nebraska, Virginia until September 21, 1894, when it was changed to Appomattox. However, due to confusion with the Old Ap pomattox Court House community, the ñamé of the post office here changed on January 15, 189 to West Appomattox, Virginia. It oper ated under that name until June 27, 1906, when it took the present name of Appomattox, Virginia. The office became third class in 1909 and second class in 1987. In mid-1955 it is scheduled to become first class, due to volume of busi ness. Several years ago it became first class, but reverted to second class due to a shift in parcel post business. The following is a list of post masters and their terms Samuel D. MeDearmon, February 23, 1855 Richard H, Mavin, December 31. 1855 Robert I, Boaz, October 4, 1866 Thomas E. Walton, December 22 1867k D- Hix, April 20, 1869 Willbfo l CoIKntf April 1 , i860 Mrs. Mary J. Atwood, February 10, 1666.  Ada A. Landrum, June 26, 1866 N. H. Gregory, October 30, 1867 Miss Elizftbéth H. Dee, Jániury 21, 188 Rufus Furdum, January 1, 1873 Samuel H. Coleman, July 26, 1889 John S. Plunkett, May 9, 1898 Robert Irby, May 7, 1897 Leslie F. Ferguson, May 20, 1918 Robert Irby, April 28, 1922 Lula G. Irby, Acting Postmaster. Ap ril 21, 921 Alfred R. Harwood, Acting Poet- master, May 15, 7931 Joseph E. Dinwiddle, June 1, 1982 E. LeRoy Smith, Acting Poet- master, June 1, 1034 Regular Appointment, March 8, 1936. However, this was not the first pqst. office in what is now Appomat tox County, Tie following inform ation  supplied by the National Archives and reports of the Post Office Department Appomattox County, Virginia The records show that this office was established on April 1, 1811, under the name of Floods, Buckings ham County, Virginia, with Thomas Trent the first postmaster. It is shown that the name oi the county was changed to Prince Edward on March 22, 1837, that the name of the office was changed to Clover Hill on July 7, 1837 and that the county in which the office was lo cated was changed to Appomattox sometime between September 23, 1845 and June 30, 1849. The re cords show that the name of the office was changed to Appomattox Court House on February 3, 1859 and changed to Appomattox on July 3, 1892.  It therefore appears that the his tory of a post office at what is now without a post office but known as Old Appomattox Court House, is equally interesting. That part of the county was in Buckingham when the post office was established as Floods in 1811. Later it became a part of Prince Edward and finally Appo mattox in 1845. Shortly after the burning of the court house in 1892, the court house was rebuilt at what is now the Town of Appomattox, and final ly the post office at the historic old village was discontinued. It was of ficially Appomattox Court House, Virginia, at the time Gen. Lee sur rendered to Gen. Grant. Undocumented stories often told here relate that in the gold rush days a hundred years and more ago?- some family started out for Ne braska, got this far and liked the place so much that they decided to settle here and call this Nebraska. This newspaper has no proof of that

document.text: Worship services will be at Hollywood Baptist Church Sunday morning July 4 at 9 a.m. Sunday School will follow at 10 oclock. Rev. Paid Balthaaer deliver ed a good message at Hollywood Sunday morning. Friends were deeply grieved to hear of the death of Rev. and Mrs. Clarence Davis infant son. We extend to them our love and deepest sympathy. Deepest sympathy is extend ed the families of Mr. John Ferguson and Mr. Curtis Blackwell. Mrs. Kenneth Deaner and daughters, Delorious Ann and Dawn spent the week end in Newport News with Mrs. loan Mayberry, Mr. and Mrs. Ryland Mayberry and Mrs. Lucy Deaner. Mrs. loan Mayberry accompanied them home for a visit. Mrs. David Austin and Janet were visitors Wednesday mor ning of Mrs. Thomas Woodall and Lisa. Mr. Frank Covington visited Mrs. M. L. Covington and Mrs. W. T. Covington Friday afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. L. L. Webb and Miss Odell Webb called in the W. H. Wingfield home Satur day afternoon. Watson, Mr. and Mrs. Scott Sheets and Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Almond. Mr. and Mrs. J. L. Torrence had their children and grand children with them for Fathers Day. Relatives and friends are so glad to hear Mrs. Frank Woodall is home from the hospital. We pray she may soon be well. Miss Joyce Webb spent a few days last week in Lynchburg with Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Woodson. Visting Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Watson Saturday were Mrs. Lee Smith and Mr. and Mrs. Larry Sexton and son. We are very sorry to hear Mr. Bennett Gilliam is back in the Lynchburg Hospital. Rev. and Mrs. Otis Sndtb and Mrs W. T. Covington visited him Sunday afternoon. We wish for him a speedy recovery. Mrs. Ruby Woodson, Lisa and Mrs. M. L. Covington visited Mrs. W. T. Covington last week. document.text: Word was received here yester day that Pfc. Alfred E. Ferguson, of Appomattox had been Blightly wounded in action in Korea on September 18. This was the first known Appomattox casualty of the Korean war. Pfc. Ferguson, 21, is the son of Bernard Ferguson and the late Mrs. Mevy Doss Ferguson. He has been in the Army about 18 months.
